title: 109_hr3248
content: The "Lifespan Respite Care Act of 2006" is added to the Public Health Service Act as Title XXIX, focusing on providing respite care for individuals in need. The "Lifespan Respite Care Act of 2006" defines terms such as 'adult with a special need' as individuals 18 years or older requiring care to meet basic needs, prevent self-injury, or avoid institutional placement. It also defines 'aging and disability resource center' as entities providing information and counseling on long-term care options. The curr_chunk discusses assessing long-term care needs, developing a personalized plan, and providing access to publicly supported programs. It defines a 'child with a special need' as someone under 18 requiring extra care for basic needs or injury prevention. The term 'eligible State agency' refers to a state agency administering long-term care programs. An eligible State agency is defined as a state agency that administers programs under specific acts, collaborates with respite care organizations, and demonstrates the ability to work with various agencies and understand caregiver issues. Family caregivers are unpaid individuals who provide in-home care for children or adults with special needs. Lifespan respite care is a system of community-based services for these caregivers. Respite care offers temporary relief to family caregivers. The District of Columbia, the Virgin Islands of the United States, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands are eligible for respite care grants and cooperative agreements to expand and enhance services for family caregivers, improve dissemination and coordination, and reduce caregiver strain. The Secretary is authorized to award grants for these purposes to eligible State agencies. The application for respite care grants must be submitted by each Governor on behalf of the eligible State agency, in accordance with subsection (d). The Secretary will collaborate with the National Family Caregiver Support Program and other respite care programs to ensure coordination of services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs. The eligible State agency's application for respite care grants must include a description of their ability to collaborate with other agencies, understanding of respite care issues across different demographics, and capacity to involve family members. It should also detail the population of family caregivers, their respite care needs, and existing services for them. The application for respite care grants must include details on the population of family caregivers, existing respite care services, coordination methods, and plans for respite care services using grant funds. The application for respite care grants must include a plan for administration, collaboration, and coordination with other services, involvement of the population in planning, utilization of various funds and resources, and availability of respite care services for family caregivers in the state. The application for respite care grants must include details on improving coordination and distribution of respite care services for family caregivers, criteria for identifying eligible caregivers, monitoring the quality and safety of services, and expected results from the proposed respite care. The application for respite care grants must include details on improving coordination and distribution of services, criteria for identifying eligible caregivers, monitoring quality and safety, expected results, confidentiality assurances, and a memorandum of agreement for joint responsibility. Priority is given to eligible State agencies showing the greatest likelihood of implementation. The Secretary prioritizes eligible State agencies that show the greatest likelihood of implementing or enhancing lifespan respite care statewide. Grant funds must be used to develop or enhance respite care, provide services for family caregivers, and train respite care workers and volunteers. The eligible State agencies awarded grants must use funds to train and recruit respite care workers, provide information to caregivers, and assist caregivers in accessing services. Optional uses of funds include training programs for family caregivers, essential services for respite care, and training for new caregivers. Each eligible State agency awarded a grant or cooperative agreement under this section may carry out activities directly or through public or private entities. A condition for receiving a grant is that the agency must provide non-Federal contributions of at least 25% of the costs, which can be in cash or in-kind contributions. The Secretary may award grants or cooperative agreements under this section for up to 5 years and may renew them. Funds must supplement, not supplant, other federal, state, and local funds for respite care services. The National Lifespan Respite Resource Center is established. The Secretary may award a grant to establish a National Resource Center on Lifespan Respite Care. The center will maintain a national database, provide training, and offer information on respite care. A report evaluating the number of states with respite care programs and caregiver demographics is due by January 1, 2009. The GAO will evaluate lifespan respite programs and report to Congress on cost benefits and service efficiency by January 1, 2011. Authorization of appropriations for the program is set at $30,000,000 for 2007, $40,000,000 for 2008, $53,330,000 for 2009, $71,110,000 for 2010, and $94,810,000 for 2011.
